title: 113_hr2318
content: The "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It pertains to federal facilities. The "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" is amending the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 regarding the application of requirements to federal facilities and the applicability of laws. The "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" amends U.S.C. 9620(a)(4) to require all U.S. government departments, agencies, and instrumentalities to comply with State hazardous waste requirements at facilities they own or operate, waiving any immunity otherwise applicable to the United States. The "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" amends U.S.C. 9620(a)(4) to require all U.S. government departments, agencies, and instrumentalities to comply with State hazardous waste requirements at facilities they own or operate. The act waives any immunity applicable to the United States with respect to State substantive or procedural requirements. Additionally, it states that the United States, its agents, employees, and officers are not immune from any process or sanction of any State or Federal Court regarding the enforcement of injunctive relief. Furthermore, no agent, employee, or officer of the United States shall be personally liable for any civil penalty under State substantive or procedural requirements. The State substantive and procedural requirements under the "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" include administrative orders, injunctive relief, civil and administrative penalties, fines, and service charges. The act removes immunity for U.S. government entities and personnel in complying with State hazardous waste regulations. The "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" includes reasonable service charges or oversight costs related to permits, reviews, attorney's fees, inspections, and monitoring of facilities or vessels. The "Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013" allows for reasonable service charges or oversight costs related to permits, reviews, attorney's fees, inspections, and monitoring of facilities or vessels, as well as any other nondiscriminatory charges in connection with State requirements for hazardous substances or pollutants. The amendment to Section 115 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 grants the Administrator the authority to review actions or regulations delegated to other departments for consistency with established guidelines.
